    Pan-SMARCA/PB1 Bromodomain Inhibitors and Their Role in Regulating Adipogenesis

    SUBJECTS:
    • Cells,

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Accessibility of the human genome is modulated by the ATP-driven SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling multiprotein complexes BAF (BRG1/BRM-associated factor) and PBAF (polybromo-associated BAF factor), which involves reading of acetylated histone tails by the bromodomain-containing proteins SMARCA2 (BRM), SMARCA4 (BRG1), and polybromo-1. Dysregulation of chromatin remodeling leads to aberrant cell proliferation and differentiation. Here, we have characterized a set of potent and cell-active bromodomain inhibitors with pan-selectivity for canonical family VIII bromodomains. Targeted SWI/SNF bromodomain inhibition blocked the expression of key genes during adipogenesis, including the transcription factors PPARγ and C/EBPα, and impaired the differentiation of 3T3-L1 murine fibroblasts into adipocytes. Our data highlight the role of SWI/SNF bromodomains in adipogenesis and provide a framework for the development of SWI/SNF bromodomain inhibitors for indirect targeting of key transcription factors regulating cell differentiation.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Access to the genetic information is primarily initiated through chromatin remodeling and epigenetic mechanisms. Errors in these processes lead to aberrant cell proliferation and abnormal cell differentiation.(1,2) Bromodomains (BRDs) are epigenetic protein–protein interaction modules involved in the regulation of gene transcription. They recognize acetylation marks or combinations of acetylated histones in addition with other epigenetic proteins. Often, multiple bromodomains are present in nuclear complexes involved in chromatin remodeling, which complicates functional studies on the epigenetic reading process. The human genome encodes 61 BRDs in 46 BRD-containing proteins, which are divided into eight families. BRDs have a highly conserved structure of ∼110 amino acids, containing four α-helices (αA, αB, αC, and αZ) that are linked by loops of varying lengths. Two of these loops (BC and ZA) form a hydrophobic pocket with a highly conserved asparagine residue that preferentially anchors acetylated lysine via a hydrogen bond.(3,4) Some BRDs have unique additional secondary structure elements, such as the BRD family VIII members with two short helical segments within the ZA loop (Figure 1a).(4) Because dysregulation of acetylation levels has been implicated in the development of many diseases such as cancer, autoimmune disorders, inflammation, heart failure, or viral infections,(5,6) chemical probes for a large set of BRDs have been developed to enable mechanistic studies on gene transcription programs and cellular disease models. Several bromodomain inhibitors, in particular targeting BET-bromodomains, have now entered clinical testing.(7−9)
    ATP-dependent switch/sucrose nonfermentable (SWI/SNF) remodeling complexes bind genome-wide to approximately 20,000–40,000 sites(10) by reading specific histone marks, leading to activation or repression of gene transcription.(11−13) They therefore play a crucial role in cell proliferation, cell differentiation and other biological processes such as muscle(14) or heart development.(15) The human SWI/SNF complexes BAF (BRG1/BRM-associated factor) and PBAF (polybromo-associated BAF factor) can be distinguished based on their subunit composition.(11) The core subunits BRG1/BRM contain an ATPase domain, a helicase domain as well as two bromodomains, SMARCA2/4 (SWI/SNF-related, matrix-associated actin-dependent regulator of chromatin, subfamily A2/4). The role of BAF as a tumor suppressor has been widely demonstrated. Loss-of-function mutations in these complexes are strong drivers of tumorigenesis, and mutations in BAF components are among the most frequently observed genetic alterations in cancer.(11) For example, development of cancer is promoted through an error to counteract polycomb repressive complexes and to remove the transcriptional silencing mark H3K27me3.(16)
    A particularly interesting PBAF component is polybromo-1 (PB1, PBRM1), which contains six distinct tandem-acting BRDs, PB1(1–6), for which no homolog is found in BAF.(11) PB1 is an important tumor suppressor, which is mutated in about 40% of clear cell renal carcinoma, making it the second most frequently mutated gene in kidney cancer after the Von-Hippel–Lindau tumor suppressor.(17) The exact role of the six tandem PB1 BRDs in PBAF, a unique feature among BRD-containing proteins, is largely unexplored, though.(18,19) Histone peptide arrays have shown that PB1(2) interacts strongly with H3K4me3 and H3K14ac, hallmarks of transcriptionally active chromatin.(4,20,21) More recently, three independent studies confirmed that PB1 binding is associated with a strong interaction of PB1(2) with H3K14ac, but also shed some light on the role of the other BRDs, for example, showing that PB1(2), PB1(4) and PB1(5) work synergistically to facilitate high affinity binding to H3K14ac and tether PB1 to chromatin.(18,22,23) The bromodomains PB1(1) and PB1(6) lack conserved residues necessary for binding to acetylated histone tails and have largely occluded binding sites and are therefore thought not to recognize acetylated sequences.(4)
    BAF and PBAF subunits are mutated in approximately 20% of all human tumors.(17,24) However, an intriguing therapeutic window exists in some cases.(25) Tumors with a SMARCA4-deficiency, for example, are vulnerable to SMARCA2 depletion,(26−29) or a BRD9-dependency was reported for SMARCB1-mutant cells.(30) Inhibition of BAF/PBAF bromodomains with small molecules, such as the BRD7/9 bromodomain inhibitors BI-7273/BI-9564 or the SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) bromodomain inhibitor PFI-3, had no significant effect on cell viability,(31−39) whereas degradation of the complex with proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs) based on BRD inhibitors has very recently been shown to efficiently kill SMARCA4- or SMARCB1-deficient cancer cells but also nonmutated cells.(40−42) However, despite the lack of antiproliferative effects, PFI-3 impairs maintenance and differentiation of embryonic and trophoblast stem cells.(43) Furthermore, it has been shown that knockdown of SMARCA4 or other BAF subunits influences self-renewal and pluripotency of embryonic stem cells and other lineage specifications.(44−46) Thus, these data indicate that SWI/SNF bromodomains play a pivotal role in regulating cell differentiation.
    Here, we were interested in the role of SWI/SNF bromodomains in adipogenesis, a process that depends on the transcription factors peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ) and CCAAT/enhancer binding protein α (C/EBPα) as well as the activity of chromatin-modifying enzymes.(47) During adipogenesis, the SWI/SNF complex interacts with the C/EBPα transactivation element III domain of C/EBPα(48) and forms a preinitiation complex with PPARγ.(49) Interestingly, genome-wide analyses revealed a high enrichment of SWI/SNF complexes on acetylated histone marks, H3K27ac and H3K9ac, in the vicinity of PPARγ binding sites during adipogenesis.(50−52) Moreover, SWI/SNF was recently shown to be enriched on specific enhancer sites that are important for lineage specification, and to interact synergistically with p300 to read H3K27ac sites.(53) These data suggest that adipocyte differentiation relies on a highly sensitive crosstalk between PPARγ, C/EBPα and SWI/SNF.
    Because of the instability of PFI-3 and its narrow activity spectrum on PB1 bromodomains, we characterized a set of potent SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) bromodomain inhibitors based on a 2-(6-aminopyridazin-3-yl)phenol scaffold. Through structure-guided design, this series was further developed into a bromodomain inhibitor with broader specificity, additionally targeting the BRD family VIII members PB1(2), PB1(3), and PB1(4). Overall, those SWI/SNF bromodomain inhibitors showed intriguing cellular activities by blocking differentiation of 3T3-L1 murine fibroblasts into adipocytes. Our data highlight the potential of SWI/SNF bromodomain inhibition to modulate cell differentiation and provide mechanistic insights into the molecular basis of adipogenesis.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Characterization of a Selective and Potent Inhibitor for BRD Family VIII

    The identification of novel chemical probes remains a priority task in pharmaceutical industry and academia. Chemical probes are selective and potent small-molecule modulators of a particular biological target, with a clearly defined mode of action, and are particularly useful for studying functional roles and molecular mechanisms of a specific target protein.(54,55) The first chemical probe for the BRDs of SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) was based on the expansion of an acetyllysine mimetic salicylic acid warhead, resulting in compound PFI-3 (1) (Figure 1d).(31,43) The unique binding mode causing the displacement of structural water molecules that are usually tightly bound in other bromodomains provided excellent selectivity of this chemical probe.(56) However, the instability of the prop-2-en-1-one motif linked to a ternary amine limited applications of this inhibitor in cellular systems that require long-term exposure. Several other inhibitors that used fused ring systems in order to improve stability such as quinazolinones(33) (2), isochromenopyrazole(34) (3) or compound DCSM06-05(35) (4) lacked potency and had limiting solubility. A recent breakthrough in developing potent and stable SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) bromodomain inhibitors was the discovery of the 2-(6-aminopyridazin-3-yl)phenol scaffold (5) published by Genentech/Constellation Pharmaceuticals in the patent literature (Figure 1d).(38) However, the authors only presented IC50 values based on TR-FRET measurements without further characterization of their inhibitors. One of those inhibitors has recently been used as a starting point for the development of PROTAC ACBI1, a chemical tool to degrade BAF/PBAF via their SMARCA2/4 and PB1 bromodomains.(41)
    To characterize this inhibitor class and to further develop them into inhibitors with an enhanced activity for a broader set of PB1 bromodomains, we resynthesized a selection of these compounds following the published protocol.(38) The general synthesis route is outlined in Scheme 1. Nucleophilic aromatic substitution of 4-bromo-6-chloropyridazin-3-amine 6 with the corresponding secondary amine yielded the intermediates 8–10, which were then converted with (2-hydroxyphenyl)boronic acid 7 or 7a to the inhibitors 22–24 and 35 using a palladium-catalyzed Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction.
    The synthesized inhibitors 22–24 and the negative control 35 were subsequently screened for selectivity within BRD subfamily VIII by differential scanning fluorimetry (DSF, Figure 2a, Table 1, Supporting Information Figure S1a–c), which measures the stabilization of the protein upon ligand binding.(57) Inhibitor 22 showed a high selectivity for SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) and resulted in moderate thermal stabilization (ΔTm) of PB1(2,3), but no significant thermostabilization when screened against a set of 16 representative members from the other seven BRD families (Figure 2b and Supporting Information Table S1). A number of clinical kinase inhibitors have been shown to also inhibit bromodomains with therapeutically relevant potencies.(58) We therefore screened inhibitor 22 against a representative panel of 85 protein kinases. No significant thermostabilization was observed in that screen, excluding those kinases as potential off targets (Table S2). Binding constants for 22 were determined by isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC), which gave dissociation constants (Kd) of 13, 35, and 36 nM for PB1(5), SMARCA2, and SMARCA4 as well as Kds of 3.7 and 2.0 μM for PB1(2) and PB1(3), respectively (Figure 2c, Table 2). Removal of the tert-butyl ester moiety in 23 reduced the ability to bind SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) by a factor of 2 (Tables 1 and 2).
    Table 1. Thermal Stabilization of BRD Family VIII Members upon Inhibitor Binding
    a

    Thermal shift ΔTm values given are the mean of triplicate measurements. The standard error of the mean was ≤±0.5 °C for all measurements. DSF assays were performed at 5 μM protein concentration and a final compound concentration of 20 μM.

    Table 2. Binding Affinities of BRD Family VIII Inhibitors
     Kd [nM]a 
    compoundPB1(2)PB1(3)PB1(4)PB1(5)SMARCA2SMARCA4log Po/wb
    223655 ± 8101963 ± 524>10 μM13 ± 235 ± 836 ± 41.82
    23   26 ± 7135 ± 1573 ± 160.74
    R-26 911 ± 1552940 ± 374   2.90
    S-27 1867 ± 282    2.77
    R-28252 ± 26328 ± 473110 ± 440238 ± 5371 ± 10100 ± 171.17
    32464 ± 44448 ± 724157 ± 49364 ± 1069 ± 1061 ± 161.14
    S,S-37892 ± 86     0.30
    S,R-39420 ± 45840 ± 133    0.26
    a

    Kd values were derived from ITC measurements and calculated by assuming a sigmoidal dose–response relationship (four parameters). The errors of the fits were calculated using standard deviation and a confidence interval of 95%.

    b

    Log Po/w values were predicted using SwissADME(87) and are given as the mean of five independent algorithms.

    To elucidate the binding mode of the compounds, we determined cocrystal structures of PB1(5) with 22 and 23 (Figure 2d,e) as well as of SMARCA4 with 23. The overall binding mode of these ligands was reminiscent of the one observed for PFI-3 (Figure 1b,c). Upon binding, the 2-(6-aminopyridazin-3-yl)phenol scaffold of the inhibitor displaces four out of five structural water molecules within the acetyl lysine binding pocket that are conserved in a multitude of BRDs.(56,59,60) In addition to extensive hydrophobic interactions, for example, with Phe684, Leu687, Pro688, and Ile745 in PB1(5), the compounds also formed specific polar contacts. The conserved Asn739 located in the BC loop formed hydrogen bonds with two nitrogens of the amino-pyridazine. In addition, the phenolic moiety of the inhibitor formed a hydrogen bond with the side chain of Tyr696, another highly conserved residue, located on a short helical segment within the ZA loop (see sequence alignment in Figure 1a). Methylation of the phenolic hydroxyl moiety in 35 completely abolished protein–ligand binding as shown by DSF (Figure 2a, Table 1), making this compound a perfect negative control. The tert-butyl ester of compound 22 formed additional hydrophobic interactions with Leu693 at the entrance of the binding pocket of PB1(5), which explained the higher affinity of 22 compared with 23 (Figure 2e). Predicted octanol–water partition coefficients (logPo/w values) of the inhibitors (Table 2) suggested a distribution between the lipid and aqueous phases in the desired range for a drug-like molecule according to Lipinski’s rule of 5.(61) Taken together, the biophysical and structural data confirmed 22 as a selective and potent inhibitor of the SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) BRDs.

    Identification of Inhibitors with Activity for PB1(2), PB1(3) and PB1(4)

    In addition to binding to SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) BRDs, most of the inhibitors also showed a moderate thermal stabilization of the second and third bromodomain of PB1 and weak activity for the fourth bromodomain (Table 1 and Figure 2a). This broader activity for bromodomains in PB1 can be rationalized by the sequence alignment of BRD subfamily VIII members in Figure 1a, showing that especially the binding region of acetylated H3 histone lysines in the ZA loop (including the short helical segment), the αB helix and the BC loop is highly conserved. In fact, most PB1(5) residues interacting with compound 23 within the acetyllysine binding pocket are either strictly conserved or have similar residue types in the different family members, apart from domains PB1(1) and PB1(6), which have occluded binding sites.
    Interestingly, it has been reported that the second, fourth and fifth bromodomain in PB1 work in tandem to recognize acetylated histones in chromatin.(18,22,23) We therefore aimed at designing a chemical probe with pan-selectivity for the functional bromodomains in subfamily VIII. To achieve this, we introduced small decorations to the core scaffold that might potentially increase the affinity for PB1(2–4) while retaining the already high affinities for SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5). Targeting the hydroxyl of a surface-exposed tyrosine (Tyr217 in PB1(2)) on the flexible ZA loop at the entrance of the binding pocket, which is only present in the second, third and fourth PB1 domain (Figure 1a), appeared particular promising to achieve the desired binding profile.
    Our initial ΔTm screens suggested the racemic inhibitor rac-25, a compound disclosed in the above-mentioned patent application by Genentech/Constellation Pharmaceuticals,(38) as a good starting point for SAR studies to develop promiscuous BRD subfamily VIII inhibitors. In particular, rac-25 gave ΔTm values of 4.9 °C for PB1(2), 6.9 °C for PB1(3), and 1.6 °C for PB1(4) (Figure 3a, Table 3). Encouraged by these data, we synthesized inhibitors 26–32, 34, and 36–39via intermediates 11–21 and 33 as outlined in Scheme 1. First, the enantiomeric pure inhibitors R-26 and S-27 were synthesized and tested by DSF. The R-enantiomer R-26 showed increased ΔTms (6.0 °C for PB1(2), 8.4 °C for PB1(3), and 2.1 °C for PB1(4)) compared with the S-enantiomer S-27 or the racemic mixture, while retaining activity for SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5). R-26 bound with a Kd of 0.9 μM for PB1(3) and 2.9 μM for PB1(4). Consistent with the DSF data, S-27 showed a reduced affinity for PB1(3) (Kd = 1.9 μM), while N-methylation of the amino-pyridazine (R-30 and S-31) completely abrogated binding to all BRDs of subfamily VIII (Figure 3a, Table 3). To elucidate the binding mode of R-26, we determined the crystal structure of PB1(2) in complex with the ligand (Figure 3d). As expected, the 2-(6-aminopyridazin-3-yl)phenol core scaffold adopted the same binding mode as its parent compound 23 in PB1(5), which was characterized by extensive hydrophobic interactions and specific hydrogen bonds to the highly conserved Asn263 on the BC loop and Tyr220 on a helical segment within the ZA loop. The piperidine moiety packed against the side chain of Tyr217 at the entrance of the binding pocket, while the phenoxy moiety was solvent exposed in the crystal structure, without specific interactions with the protein. The phenoxy ether formed an intramolecular hydrogen bond with the primary amine of the ligand.
    Table 3. Thermal Stabilization of BRD Family VIII Members upon Inhibitor Binding
    a

    DSF assays were performed at a protein concentration of 5 μM and a final compound concentration of 20 μM. ΔTm values are the mean of triplicate measurements. The standard error of the mean was ≤±0.5 °C, unless stated otherwise.

    b

    Standard error of the mean ≤±1.0 °C.

    A drawback of compound R-26 was its low aqueous solubility (Table 2), which hampered further studies. To increase the aqueous solubility of R-26, we removed the phenyl ring to yield inhibitors R-28 and S-29, as this hydrophobic moiety was solvent-exposed in the crystal structure of PB1(2) in complex with R-26 and did not significantly interact with the bromodomain. Consistent with the R-26/S-27 pair, the R-enantiomer of the shortened compound, R-28, preferentially bound to PB1(2,3,4) compared with its enantiomer S-29 (see DSF data in Table 3), with dissociation constants of 252 nM, 328 nM, and 3.1 μM for PB1(2), PB1(3), and PB1(4), respectively (Supporting Information Figure S2, Tables 2 and S3). As such, the affinity of R-28 for PB1(3) was almost three times higher than the one of its less water-soluble precursor molecule R-26. Importantly, R-28 retained high affinities for SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5), with Kd values of 71, 100 and 238 nM, respectively (Table 2).
    Next, the piperidine ring of the inhibitor was modified to engineer a hydrogen bond with Tyr217 by introducing either a hydroxyl group (32) or a ketone (34) at position 4 (synthesized via intermediate 33). The ketone-based inhibitor 34 bound more weakly to bromodomains of subfamily VIII, suggesting that the chair conformation of the piperidine was necessary for optimal binding. In contrast, compound 32 showed increased binding affinity for PB1(2,3,4) compared with 24, indicating that Tyr217 may be targeted by this modification as anticipated. This novel interaction, which has not been exploited before, was confirmed by a crystal structure of PB1(2) in complex with 32 at high resolution (1.14 Å) (Figure 3e). Somewhat unexpectedly, this novel interaction did not further increase binding affinity for the second, third or fourth PB1 bromodomain compared with compound R-28 (Table 2, Figure 3c, Supporting Information Table S3).
    Based on these results, inhibitor decorations in R-28 and 32 were merged because both inhibitors showed good to moderate affinities for PB1(2,3,4) and retained binding to PB1(5) and SMARCA2/4. As building blocks, the respective cis and trans isomers of piperidine-3,4-diol with relative configurations were used, followed by chiral purification on an i-amylose-1 LC column to obtain the four absolute stereoisomers 36–39 with a purity of >95% ee (Table 3, Supporting Information data chiral HPLC). The absolute stereochemistry was determined by cocrystal structures with PB1(5). S,R-39 was the most potent of the four diastereomers in our biophysical assays (Tables 2 and 3), but unfortunately none of those inhibitors improved binding affinity compared with R-28 or 32.
    Notably, the affinity of the pan-inhibitors for PB1(4) was on average about 10 times lower than for PB1(2) and PB1(3). This was most likely due to a unique sequence variation at the bottom of the binding pocket of PB1(4). In the complex of PB1(2) with R-26 or 32, the phenolic moiety of the inhibitor formed hydrophobic interactions with the side chain of Leu211, among others (Figure 3d,e). This residue is conserved in the other BRDs as shown in the sequence alignment in Figure 1a, except for PB1(4), which contains a lysine at this position (Lys549) that points away from the binding pocket (Figure 3e). This loss of hydrophobic interaction may therefore account for the observed reduction in binding affinity for PB1(4).
    Taken together, our data establish R-28 and 32 as pan-inhibitors of BRD subfamily VIII with moderate to good affinities for PB1(2,3,4,5) and SMARCA2/4 BRDs. Both compounds are, therefore, valuable molecules, in addition to 22 and the negative control compound 35, for exploring SWI/SNF-related biology in normal physiology and diseases.

    Effects of SMARCA/PB1 Bromodomain Inhibitors on Cell Proliferation and Cell Differentiation

    The chromatin remodeling complexes BAF and PBAF influence stem cell differentiation and gene expression, and they are frequently mutated in cancer. We therefore investigated the effects of 22 and R-28 on cell proliferation in two colorectal (HCT116, HT29) and two breast (MCF-7, MDA-MB-231) cancer cell lines that have shown a dependency on SMARCA2/4.(62−64) Both inhibitors had no significant effect on metabolic activity in a cell viability assay using 2,3-bis-[(2-methoxy-4-nitro-5-sulfophenyl)-2H-tetrazolium-5-carboxanilide salt] (XTT) and N-methyl dibenzopyrazine methyl sulfate (PMS) in treatment doses of up to 50 μM after 4 days (Supporting Information Figure S3a–d). Compound 22 was also tested in the NCI-60 Human Cancer Cell Line Screen, again without any noticeable antiproliferative effects (Supporting Information Figure S4). These findings are consistent with earlier studies where PFI-3 had been profiled in twelve primary human cell-based systems without showing significant effects in a BioMAP screen run at short incubation times for detection of direct effects on gene transcription.(31)
    SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes have been linked to several metabolic diseases(47) and cell differentiation processes.(65,66) Because SWI/SNF chromatin remodelers play regulatory roles during adipocyte differentiation, we tested compounds 22, R-28, and 32 in an adipogenesis assay using 3T3-L1 murine fibroblasts (Figures 4a and Supporting Information S5). Differentiation of fibroblasts into adipocytes was induced by an activation cocktail (isobutylmethylxanthine (IBMX), insulin and dexamethasone) and addition of PPARγ agonist rosiglitazone at a final concentration of 2 μM. Intracellular lipid accumulation was measured 14 days after stimulation by oil red O staining. Using this setup, 3T3-L1 murine fibroblasts were cotreated with two concentrations of 22, R-28, 32, the negative control 35 and PFI-3 (1.0 and 5.0 μM). As expected, rosiglitazone alone induced adipocyte formation and led to robust lipid droplet accumulation. Cotreatment with PFI-3 impaired adipocyte differentiation only slightly at a final concentration of 5.0 μM. The modest effects of this inhibitor were probably due to its limiting long-term stability in aqueous environments because of its reactive Michael acceptor system.(31) In contrast, 22, R-28, and 32 blocked adipocyte differentiation at 1.0 μM in 3T3-L1 murine fibroblasts, while the negative control 35 did not affect lipid droplet accumulation at both concentrations tested.

    SMARCA/PB1 Bromodomain Inhibition Blocks the Expression of Key Genes during Adipogenesis

    To provide further mechanistic insights into the effects of SWI/SNF bromodomain inhibition during adipogenesis, we analyzed mRNA levels of key transcriptional regulators by qPCR within the first five days after stimulation of adipogenesis (Figures 4b and Supporting Information S6). The investigated target genes comprised the transcription factors PPARγ, C/EBPα, Krüppel-like factor 5 (KLF5) and early growth response protein 2 (Krox20) as well as the fatty acid-binding protein 4 (FABP4), which have all been implicated with adipogenesis.
    During the early stages of adipogenesis (0–1 days), transcription factors C/EBPβ and C/EBPδ are upregulated to promote preadipocytes to differentiate into adipocytes.(67) This upregulation is enhanced through increased expression of KLF5(68) and Krox20.(69) Then on days 1–3, C/EBPβ and C/EBPδ are usually downregulated, while C/EBPα and PPARγ are upregulated, leading to an accumulation of these late adipogenic transcription factors in matured adipocytes (3–7 days).(47,70,71) Terminal differentiation is marked by elevated levels of insulin-regulated glucose transporter GLUT4, adiponectin, and FABP4.(72−74)
    The observed changes in mRNA levels upon inhibitor treatment (Figure 4b) were in line with the phenotypic changes. Expression levels of the positive regulators of adipogenesis, PPARγ and C/EBPα, and the downstream marker of matured adipocytes, FABP4, were remarkably reduced after addition of inhibitor 22 to rosiglitazone treated cells. The negative control compound 35, did not affect the expression of these three genes, showing that the reduced expression levels with 22 were indeed due to on-target effects of the inhibitor. Compared with inhibitor PFI-3, 22 reduced the mRNA levels of PPARγ, C/EBPα, and FABP4 more efficiently even at 10 times lower doses. After 5 days, for example, FABP4 was almost completely downregulated to the level of the control culture without rosiglitazone. Interestingly, the mRNA levels of Krox20 and KLF5, positive regulators of the very early stage of adipogenesis, were not affected by the treatment (Supporting Information Figure S6), suggesting that expression of these transcription factors was independent of bromodomain family VIII action.
    Taken together, our inhibition experiments showed that the bromodomains of SWI/SNF are directly involved in adipogenesis by regulating the expression of key adipogenic transcription factors PPARγ and C/EBPα as well as of adipogenesis marker FABP4.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Here, we have characterized a set of potent inhibitors, based on a 2-(6-aminopyridazin-3-yl)phenol scaffold, for the bromodomains SMARCA2/4 and PB1 of chromatin remodeling complexes BAF and PBAF. Inhibitor 22 was highly selective within a panel of 25 BRDs and strongly bound to SMARCA2/4 and PB1(5) with dissociation constants of 35, 36 and 13 nM, respectively. Structure-guided modification of 22 led to compounds R-28 and 32 with pan-selectivity for the bromodomains of subfamily VIII with increased binding affinities for the BRDs PB1(2), PB1(3), and PB1(4). In the process, the first inhibitor-bound crystal structures of PB1(2) were determined. Intriguingly, compounds 22, R-28, and 32 blocked adipogenesis of 3T3-L1 murine fibroblasts by reducing the mRNA levels of key markers of adipocyte differentiation, PPARγ, C/EBPα, and FABP4. The presented SWI/SNF inhibitors provide valuable tools for studying the molecular mechanisms of adipogenesis and other SWI/SNF-dependent lineage specifications.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Compound Synthesis

    The structures of the synthesized compounds were verified by 1H- and 13C NMR, and mass spectrometry (ESI). Compound purity (254 and 280 nm >95%) was determined by analytical HPLC. All commercial chemicals and solvents were used without further purification. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were measured in DMSO-d6 or CDCl3 on a Bruker DPX250, AV400, or AV500 spectrometer. Chemical shifts δ are reported in parts per million (ppm). Mass spectra were recorded by the mass spectrometry service team of the Goethe University using a Thermo Fisher Surveyor MSQ system (including TLC-MS for reaction control). High-resolution mass spectra were recorded on a MALDI LTQ ORBITRAP XL device from Thermo Fisher Scientific. Product purification was performed on a Reveleris Prep Flash Column Chromatography System from Grace/Büchi using prepacked silica or RP C18 columns. Product purification was also performed on an Agilent 1260 Infinity II LC System [Eclipse XDB-C18 column (7 μM, 21.2 × 250 mm)] using a gradient of water/MeCN + 0.1% TFA (98:2–5:95) over 40 min with a flow rate of 21 mL/min. Compound purity was analyzed on an Agilent 1260 Infinity II LC System [Eclipse XDB-C18 column (4.6 × 250 mm, 5 μm)] coupled to an Agilent InifinityLab LC/MSD using a gradient of water/MeCN + 0.1% TFA (98:2–5:95) over 25 min at a flow rate of 1 mL/min (see the Supporting Information data for HPLC–MS traces of lead compounds).
    Final compounds 22–39 were synthesized from 4-bromo-6-chloropyridazin-3-amine 6via intermediates 8–21 as outlined in Scheme 1.

    tert-Butyl 4-(3-amino-6-chloro-pyridazin-4-yl)piperazine-1-carboxylate (8)

    General procedure A: Adapted from a patent procedure,(38) 4-bromo-6-chloropyridazin-3-amine 6 (2.00 g, 9.59 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and Boc-piperazine (3.57 g, 19.2 mmol, 2.0 eq) were suspended in dry MeCN (10 mL). After adding DIEA (8.2 mL, 48 mmol, 5.0 equiv), the reaction mixture was stirred at 82 °C overnight. After complete educt conversion, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and then extracted with 10 mL water and EtOAc (3 × 15 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with sat. NaHCO3 (aq) (5 mL) and brine (5 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The crude product was deposited onto silica and purified by flash silica column chromatography using cyclohexane/EtOAc (20–100%) as eluent to yield intermediate 8 (2.43 g, 7.74 mmol, 81%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 6.71 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 5.26 (s, 2H, NH2), 3.57 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-3), 2.99 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-2), 1.47 (s, 9H, tert-butyl-(CH3)3); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 155.4, 154.6, 148.2, 141.4, 115.8, 80.5, 49.0, 28.5; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C13H20ClN5O2 + H]+ calcd, 314.13 (35Cl), 316.13 (37Cl); found, 314.21.

    tert-Butyl 4-[3-amino-6-(2-hydroxyphenyl)pyridazin-4-yl]piperazine-1-carboxylate (22)

    General procedure B: Adapted from a patent procedure,(38) a microwave-suitable flask was charged with 8 (850 mg, 2.71 mmol, 1.0 equiv), (2-hydroxyphenyl)boronic acid 7 (747 mg, 5.42 mmol, 2.0 equiv), K2CO3 (824 mg, 5.96 mmol, 2.2 equiv), XPhos Gen. 3 (229 mg, 0.271 mmol, 0.1 equiv) and an argon-purged 1:1 mixture of 15 mL H2O/MeCN (181 mmol/L). The reaction mixture was irradiated in the microwave under dynamic conditions at 120 °C for 60 min until the complete educt was converted as indicated by TLC. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with sat. NaHCO3 (5 mL) and brine (5 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and the solvent was removed in vacuo. The crude product was deposited onto silica and purified by flash silica column chromatography using cyclohexane/EtOAc (20–70%) to yield the pure product 22 (760 mg, 205 mmol, 76%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 13.73 (s, 1H, OH), 7.56 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-3), 7.29 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 7.27 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-5), 7.04 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-6), 6.90 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-4), 4.98 (s, 2H, NH2), 3.63 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-3), 3.08 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-2), 1.49 (s, 9H, tert-butyl (CH3)3; 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 159.3, 155.2, 154.6, 154.3, 141.0, 131.0, 125.2, 118.8, 118.6, 117.5, 111.1, 80.5, 49.3, 28.5; HRMS-ESI (m/z): for [C19H25N5O3 + H]+ calcd, 372.203; found, 372.204. HPLC–UV (254 nm) = 98.9%, (280 nm) = 99.3%.

    6-Chloro-4-morpholino-pyridazin-3-amine (9)

    6 (400 mg, 1.92 mmol) was reacted with morpholine according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 20–100% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound 9 (214 mg, 0.997 mmol, 52%) as a bright yellow solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 6.89 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 6.22 (s, 2H, NH2), 3.75 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, morpholin-2(CH2)-3), 2.98 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, morpholin-2(CH2)-2); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 155.4, 145.8, 140.5, 114.5, 65.6, 48.6; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C8H11ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 215.06 (35Cl), 217.06 (37Cl); found, 215.04, 217.05.

    6-Chloro-4-[(rac)-3-phenoxy-1-piperidyl]-pyridazin-3-amine (Rac-10)

    6 (200 mg, 0.959 mmol) was reacted with rac-3-phenoxypiperidine according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 20–100% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound rac-10 (178 mg, 0.584 mmol, 61%) as a slightly yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 7.31 (t, J = 7.06 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(m)-CH), 6.99 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H, phenyl-(p)-CH), 6.93 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(o)-CH), 6.71 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 5.10 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.58–4.52 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax/eq), 3.55 (dd, J = 12.4 Hz, J = 4.9 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.16–3.11 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 3.05–3.02 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-6eq/2eq), 2.11–1.96 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-5ax/4ax), 1.94–1.83 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.77–1.68 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 156.9, 155.2, 148.0, 141.4, 129.9, 121.7, 116.1, 115.4, 71.1, 52.8, 49.6, 28.0, 21.8; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C15H17ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 305.11 (35Cl), 307.11 (37Cl); found, 305.16, 307.17.

    6-Chloro-4-[(3R)-3-phenoxy-1-piperidyl]-pyridazin-3-amine (R-11)

    6 (100 mg, 0.480 mmol) was reacted with (3R)-3-phenoxypiperidine (1.4 equiv) according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 10–70% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound R-11 (71 mg, 0.233 mmol, 49%) as a slightly yellow solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 7.30 (dd, J = 8.6 Hz, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(m)-CH), 6.99 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H, phenyl-(p)-CH), 6.93 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(o)-CH), 6.70 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 5.10 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.61–4.53 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax), 3.54 (dd, J = 12.3 Hz, J = 4.6 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.23–3.09 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 3.09–2.88 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-6eq/2eq), 2.10–1.95 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-5ax/4ax), 1.93–1.85 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.79–1.61 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 156.9, 155.2, 148.0, 141.4, 129.8, 121.6, 116.0, 115.4, 71.0, 52.8, 49.6, 28.0, 21.8; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C15H17ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 305.11 (35Cl), 307.11 (37Cl); found, 305.09, 307.10.

    6-Chloro-4-[(3S)-3-phenoxy-1-piperidyl]-pyridazin-3-amine (S-12)

    6 (120 mg, 0.576 mmol) was reacted with (3S)-3-phenoxypiperidine (1.4 equiv) according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 10–100% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound S-12 (103 mg, 0.380 mmol, 59%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 7.30 (dd, J = 8.7 Hz, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(m)-CH), 6.98 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H, phenyl-(p)-CH), 6.93 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(o)-CH), 6.70 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 5.14 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.62–4.47 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3eq), 3.54 (dd, J = 12.3 Hz, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.28–3.08 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 3.08–2.88 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-6eq/2eq), 2.13–1.94 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-5ax/4ax), 1.93–1.84 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.77–1.65 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 156.9, 155.2, 148.0, 141.4, 129.8, 121.6, 116.0, 115.4, 71.0, 52.8, 49.6, 28.0, 21.8; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C15H17ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 305.11 (35Cl), 307.11 (37Cl); found, 305.09, 307.10.

    (3R)-1-(3-Amino-6-chloro-pyridazin-4-yl)piperidin-3-ol (R-13)

    6 (417 mg, 2.00 mmol) was reacted with (3R)-piperidin-3-ol hydrochloride according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 1–10% DCM/MeOH to yield compound R-13 (108 mg, 0.472 mmol, 23%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 6.84 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 6.09 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.93 (d, J = 5.1 Hz, 1H, OH), 3.78–3.72 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax), 3.13 (dd, J = 11.7, 2.5 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.10–3.01 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 2.75 (t, J = 9.2 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-6eq), 2.67 (dd, J = 11.6, 7.5 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2eq), 1.87–1.71 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-5ax/4ax), 1.65–1.53 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.47–1.32 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 155.6, 145.9, 141.2, 114.3, 64.5, 55.2, 48.7, 32.1, 21.8; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C9H13ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 229.08 (35Cl), 231.07 (37Cl); found, 229.03, 231.05.

    (3S)-1-(3-Amino-6-chloro-pyridazin-4-yl)piperidin-3-ol (S-14)

    6 (379 mg, 1.82 mmol) was reacted with (3S)-piperidin-3-ol hydrochloride according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 1–10% DCM/MeOH to yield compound S-14 (244 mg, 1.07 mmol, 59%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 6.84 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 6.09 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.93 (d, J = 5.1 Hz, 1H, OH), 3.78–3.72 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3eq), 3.13 (dd, J = 11.7, 2.6 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.10–3.01 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 2.74 (t, J = 9.2 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-6eq), 2.67 (dd, J = 11.6, 7.5 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2eq), 1.87–1.71 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-5ax/4ax), 1.65–1.53 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.47–1.32 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 155.6, 145.9, 141.2, 114.3, 64.5, 55.2, 48.7, 32.11, 21.85; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C9H13ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 229.08 (35Cl), 231.07 (37Cl); found, 229.03, 231.05.

    6-Chloro-4-(1,4-dioxa-8-azaspiro[4.5]decan-8-yl)pyridazine-3-amine (15)

    6 (500 mg, 2.40 mmol) was reacted with 1,4-dioxa-8-azaspiro[4.5]decane according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 20–100% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound 15 (468 mg, 1.73 mmol, 72%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 6.72 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 5.27 (s, 2H, NH2), 3.98 (s, 4H, 2(OCH2)), 3.13 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, piperidine-2(CH2)-2), 1.84 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, piperidine-2(CH2)-3); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 155.4, 148.1, 141.8, 115.6, 106.2, 64.5, 47.4, 35.0; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C11H15ClN4O2 + H]+ calcd, 271.09 (35Cl), 273.09 (37Cl); found, 271.14, 273.14.

    1-(3-Amino-6-chloro-pyridazin-4-yl)piperidin-4-ol (16)

    6 (500 mg, 2.40 mmol) was reacted with piperidin-4-ol according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 1–10% DCM/MeOH to yield compound 16 (244 mg, 1.07 mmol, 45%) as a slightly yellow solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 6.85 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 6.05 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.74 (d, J = 3.8 Hz, 1H, OH), 3.71–3.58 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4), 3.28–3.15 (m, 2H, piperidine-2(CH)-2ax), 2.79–2.65 (m, 2H, piperidine-2(CH)-2eq), 1.90–1.77 (m, 2H, piperidine-2(CH)-3ax), 1.68–1.47 (m, 2H, piperidine-2(CH)-3eq).; 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 155.5, 145.9, 141.4, 114.2, 65.3, 46.2, 33.5; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C9H13ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 229.08 (35Cl), 231.07 (37Cl); found, 229.03, 231.05.

    4-Bromo-6-chloro-N-methyl-pyridazin-3-amine (17)

    To a suspension of 6 (1.00 g, 4.80 mmol) in dry THF (35 mL) at 0 °C was added first NaH (60% mineral oil, 288 mg, 1.5 equiv, 7.20 mmol), followed by 2 M iodomethane in tert-butylmethylether (2.5 mL, 1.05 equiv, 5.04 mmol) after 15 min stirring. The reaction mixture was allowed to warm to room temperature and was then stirred overnight at 40 °C. The reaction was quenched by pouring into a sat. NH4Cl (aq) solution. The solution was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 20 mL), the organic layer was separated and dried over MgSO4, filtered, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was deposited onto silica and purified by flash silica column chromatography using 10–50% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound 17 (390 mg, 1.75 mmol, 37%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 7.46 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 5.13 (s, 1H, NH), 3.14 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 3H, CH3); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 155.6, 145.0, 130.7, 116.9, 29.4; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C5H5BrClN3 + H]+ calcd, for 35Cl, 37Cl, 79Br, 81Br: 221.94, 223.93, 223.93, 225.93; found, 221.92, 223.92, 225.87.

    6-Chloro-N-methyl-4-[(3S)-3-phenoxy-1-piperidyl]-pyridazin-3-amine (S-18)

    17 (100 mg, 0.449 mmol) was reacted with (3S)-3-phenoxypiperidine (1.5 equiv) according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 10–70% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound S-18 (91 mg, 0.285 mmol, 64%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 7.32 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(m)-CH), 6.99 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H, phenyl-(p)-CH), 6.94 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(o)-CH), 6.62 (s, 1H pyridazine-CH), 5.13–5.02 (m, 1H, NH), 4.63–4.50 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3eq), 3.54 (d, J = 10.1 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.11–2.97 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH-6ax/6eq), 2.89 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 3H, CH3), 2.84 (d, J = 12.5 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2eq), 2.12–2.01 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-5ax/4ax), 1.90–1.78 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.77–1.65 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 156.8, 154.0, 146.7, 141.6, 129.9, 121.5, 115.6, 114.7, 70.5, 52.8, 49.8, 28.7, 27.9, 21.6; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C16H19ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 319.12 (35Cl), 321.12 (37Cl); found, 319.06, 321.07.

    6-Chloro-N-methyl-4-[(3R)-3-phenoxy-1-piperidyl]-pyridazin-3-amine (R-19)

    17 (200 mg, 0.899 mmol) was reacted with (3R)-3-phenoxypiperidine (1.5 equiv) according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 10–70% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield com/pound R-19 (156 mg, 0.489 mmol, 54%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 7.33 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(m)-CH), 7.00 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H, phenyl-(p)-CH), 6.94 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(o)-CH), 6.63 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 5.11–4.98 (m, 1H, NH), 4.61–4.53 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax), 3.56 (d, J = 10.3 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.11–2.95 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH-6ax/6eq), 2.91 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 3H, CH3), 2.84 (d, J = 12.6 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2eq), 2.12–2.02 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-5ax/4ax), 1.90–1.78 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.77–1.68 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 156.9, 154.1, 146.7, 141.6, 130.0, 121.6, 115.6, 114.7, 70.5, 52.9, 49.9, 28.7, 28.0, 21.6; MS-ESI (m/z): for [C16H19ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 319.12 (35Cl), 321.12 (37Cl); found, 319.03, 321.03.

    trans-1-(3-Amino-6-chloro-pyridazin-4-yl)piperidine-3,4-diol (Trans-20)

    6 (200 mg, 0.959 mmol) was reacted with trans-piperidine-3,4-diol hydrochloride (1.7 equiv) according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash C18 column chromatography using water/MeCN + 0.1% TFA (98/2–5/95) to yield trans-20 (90 mg, 0.368 mmol, 38%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, d4-MeOH): δ [ppm] 6.93 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 3.68–3.64 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax/eq), 3.62–3.59 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4ax/eq), 3.40 (dd, J = 12.2, 2.4 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.37–3.32 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 2.91–2.80 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH-6eq/2eq), 2.15–2.05 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5ax), 1.76–1.68 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq). 13C NMR (125 MHz, d4-MeOH): δ [ppm] 157.0, 148.3, 143.8, 116.4, 72.0, 71.5, 53.1, 47.4, 31.5. MS-ESI (m/z): for [C9H13ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 245.07 (35Cl), 247.07 (37Cl); found, 245.08, 247.10.

    cis-1-(3-Amino-6-chloro-pyridazin-4-yl)piperidine-3,4-diol (Cis-21)

    6 (200 mg, 0.959 mmol) was reacted with cis-piperidine-3,4-diol hydrochloride (1.7 equiv) according to general procedure A. Purification was performed by flash C18 column chromatography using water/MeCN + 0.1% TFA (98/2–5/95) to yield cis-21 (36 mg, 0.147 mmol, 15%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, d4-MeOH): δ [ppm] 6.93 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 3.92–3.90 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax/eq), 3.80 (dt, J = 9.0, 3.7 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-4ax/eq), 3.47 (dd, J = 12.3, 5.0 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.30–3.23 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 3.01–2.92 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6eq), 2.90 (dd, J = 12.6, 1.9 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2eq), 2.03–1.95 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5ax), 1.85–1.82 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq). 13C NMR (125 MHz, d4-MeOH): δ [ppm] 157.0, 148.2, 143.9, 116.4, 69.8, 69.3, 52.8, 47.4, 30.0. MS-ESI (m/z): for [C9H13ClN4O + H]+ calcd, 245.07 (35Cl), 247.07 (37Cl); found, 245.07, 247.10.

    2-(6-Amino-5-piperazin-1-yl-pyridazin-3-yl)phenol Hydrochloride (23)

    Compound 22 (500 mg, 1.35 mmol) was treated with 10 mL of a 4 M HCl solution in 1,4-dioxan for 2 h at room temperature. The resulting precipitate was filtered through a Büchner funnel, washed with 10 mL 1,4-dioxan, 5 mL DCM and finally dried under reduced pressure to give 23 (414 mg, 1.35 mmol, quant.) as a white HCl-solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 10. 96 (br s, 1H, OH), 9.84 (s, 2H, piperazine-NH·HCl), 7.79 (br s, 3H, NH2·HCl), 7.62 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 7.57 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-3), 7.37 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-5), 7.15 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-6), 6.96 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-4), 3.47 (br s, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-2), 3.32 (br s, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-3); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 155.6, 132.2, 129.9, 119.5, 116.7, 45.4, 41.8; HRMS-ESI (m/z): for [C14H17N5O + H]+ calcd, 272.150; found, 272.149. HPLC–UV (254 nm) = 99.8%, (280 nm) = 98.9%.

    2-(6-Amino-5-morpholino-pyridazin-3-yl)phenol (24)

    9 (100 mg, 0.466 mmol) was reacted with (2-hydroxyphenyl)boronic acid 7 according to general procedure B.     2-[6-Amino-5-[(3R)-3-phenoxy-1-piperidyl]pyridazin-3-yl]phenol (R-26)

    R-11 (100 mg, 0.328 mmol) was reacted with (2-hydroxyphenyl)boronic acid 7 according to general procedure B. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 1–10% DCM/MeOH, followed by a preparative RP-C18-HPLC separation with a gradient (98–5%) of H2O/MeCN and 0.1% TFA. The product fractions were combined and the solvents were removed under reduced pressure. To remove TFA excess the product was dissolved in 2 mL CHCl3 with 50 mg NaHCO3. The mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature, filtered through a spin column and finally dried to yield compound R-26 (68 mg, 0.188 mmol, 58%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 13.81 (s, 1H, OH), 7.55 (dd, J = 8.0, 1.2 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-3), 7.30 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(m)-CH), 7.27–7.21 (m, 2H, pyridazine-CH/phenol-CH-5), 7.02 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-6), 6.98 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H, phenyl-(p)-CH), 6.94 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H, phenyl-(o)-CH), 6.87 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-4), 5.12 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.62–4.51 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax), 3.59 (dd, J = 12.1, 4.1 Hz, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.29–3.15 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 3.15–2.99 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH2-6eq/2eq), 2.14–1.97 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH-5ax/4ax), 1.95–1.84 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4eq), 1.79–1.69 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 159.3, 156.9, 154.8, 154.3, 141.1, 130.7, 129.9, 125.2, 121.6, 118.7, 118.4, 117.7, 116.0, 110.7, 71.1, 53.1, 49.7, 28.0, 21.9; HRMS-ESI (m/z): for [C21H22N4O2 + H]+ calcd, 363.181; found, 363.182. HPLC–UV (254 nm) = 98.2%, (280 nm) = 98.3%.

Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 1–5% DCM/MeOH, followed by a preparative RP-C18-HPLC separation with a gradient (98–5%) of H2O/MeCN and 0.1% TFA.     2-[6-Amino-5-(1,4-dioxa-8-azaspiro[4.5]decan-8-yl)pyridazin-3-yl]phenol (33)

    15 (150 mg, 0.554 mmol) was reacted with (2-hydroxyphenyl)boronic acid 7 according to general procedure B.     1-[3-Amino-6-(2-hydroxyphenyl)pyridazin-4-yl]piperidin-4-one (34)

    33 (35 mg, 0.107 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL THF. After adding 1 mL 6 M HCl solution, the reaction mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature. The reaction was quenched by adding 15 mL of sat. aq NaHCO3 solution, which was then extracted with EtOAc (4 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with water (3 × 10 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was deposited onto silica and purified by flash silica column chromatography using 20–100% cyclohexane/EtOAc to yield compound 34 (30 mg, 0.070 mmol, 66%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 7.92 (d, J = 7.1 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-3), 7.59 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 7.24 (td, J = 7.0, 1.5 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-5), 6.97–6.83 (m, 2H, phenol-CH-6/4), 6.48 (d, J = 4.9 Hz, 2H, NH2), 3.41 (t, J = 5.9 Hz, 4H, piperidine-2(CH2)-2), 2.62 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 4H, piperidine-2(CH2)-3); 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 207.3, 158.4, 154.8, 153.1, 139.8, 130.1, 126.2, 118.5, 117.8, 117.3, 111.3, 48.1, 40.5; HRMS-ESI (m/z): for [C15H16N4O2 + H]+ calcd, 285.135; found, 285.138. HPLC–UV (254 nm) = 97.5%, (280 nm) = 97.2%.

    tert-Butyl 4-[3-amino-6-(2-methoxyphenyl)yridazine-4-yl]piperazine-1-carboxylate (35)

    8 (55 mg, 0.175 mmol) was reacted with (2-methoxyphenyl)boronic acid 7a according to general procedure B. Purification was performed by flash silica column chromatography using 1–10% DCM/MeOH to yield compound 35 (42 mg, 0.109 mmol, 62%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 7.77 (dd, J = 7.6, 1.7 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-3), 7.36 (ddd, J = 8.3, 7.6, 1.8 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-5), 7.26 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 7.06 (td, J = 7.5, 0.9 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-4), 6.97 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-6), 5.27 (s, 2H, NH2), 3.82 (s, 3H, OCH3), 3.59 (t, J = 5.0 Hz, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-3), 3.00 (t, J = 4.5 Hz, 4H, piperazine-2(CH2)-2), 1.47 (s, 9H, tert-butyl (CH3)3); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ [ppm] 156.7, 154.7, 154.6, 152.9, 138.2, 130.8, 130.1, 126.8, 121.2, 117.1, 111.3, 80.2, 55.7, 49.2, 28.4; HRMS-ESI (m/z): for [C20H27N5O3 + H]+ calcd, 386.211; found, 386.212. HPLC–UV (254 nm) = 99.2%, (280 nm) = 99.5%.

    (3R,4R)-1-[3-Amino-6-(2-hydroxyphenyl)pyridazine-4-yl]piperidine-3,4-diol (R,R-36) and (3S,4S)-1-[3-Amino-6-(2-hydroxyphenyl)pyridazine-4-yl]piperidine-3,4-diol (S,S-37)

    Trans-20 (80 mg, 0.327 mmol) was reacted with (2-hydroxyphenyl)boronic acid 7 according to general procedure B. Purification was performed by flash C18 column chromatography using water/MeCN + 0.1% TFA (98/2–5/95) to yield the trans-mixture (34 mg, 0.112 mmol, 34%). Chiral preparative separation (1–2 mg/HPLC run) and chiral analytics were performed on an Agilent HPLC using a chiral i-Amylose-I LC column (see section: chiral separation of racemic mixture for details) to yield R,R-36 and S,S-37. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 7.91 (dd, J = 8.3, 1.3 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-3), 7.50 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 7.23 (dt, J = 8.1, 1.2 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-5), 6.91–6.84 (m, 2H, phenol-CH-6/4), 6.27 (s, 2H, NH2), 5.10 (d, J = 5.1 Hz, 1H, piperidine-OH-3), 4.91 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H, piperidine-OH-4), 3.58–3.52 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax/eq), 3.49–3.44 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4ax/eq), 3.34–3.27 (m, 2H, piperidine-CH-2ax/6ax), 2.89–2.83 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6eq), 2.82–2.77 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-2eq), 2.02–1.94 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5ax), 1.68–1.60 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 158.6, 154.8, 153.2, 140.7, 130.1, 126.2, 118.5, 117.8, 117.4, 110.4, 70.1, 69.8, 52.1, 46.1, 30.3; HRMS-ESI (m/z): for [C15H18N4O3 + H]+ calcd, 303.145; found, 303.145.

    (3R,4S)-1-[3-Amino-6-(2-hydroxyphenyl)pyridazine-4-yl]piperidine-3,4-diol (R,S-38) and (3S,4R)-1-[3-Amino-6-(2-hydroxyphenyl)pyridazine-4-yl]piperidine-3,4-diol (S,R-39)

    Cis-21 (36 mg, 0.147 mmol) was reacted with (2-hydroxyphenyl)boronic acid 7 according to general procedure B. Purification was performed by flash C18 column chromatography using water/MeCN + 0.1% TFA (98/2–5/95) to yield the cis-mixture (16 mg, 0.053 mmol, 36%). Chiral preparative separation (1–2 mg/HPLC run) and chiral analytics were performed on an Agilent HPLC using a chiral i-Amylose-I LC column (see section: chiral separation of racemic mixtures for details) to yield R,S-38 and S,R-39. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 7.90 (dd, J = 8.3, 1.3 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-3), 7.49 (s, 1H, pyridazine-CH), 7.23 (dt, J = 15.3, 1.4 Hz, 1H, phenol-CH-5), 6.92–6.83 (m, 2H, phenol-CH-6/4), 6.31 (s, 2H, NH2), 4.87 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 1H, piperidine-OH-3), 4.65 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H, piperidine-OH-4), 3.82–3.77 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-3ax/eq), 3.71–3.67 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-4ax/eq), 3.32–3.27 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-2ax), 3.25–3.17 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6ax), 3.03–2.96 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-6eq), 2.94–2.87 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-2eq), 1.91–1.82 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5ax), 1.79–1.70 (m, 1H, piperidine-CH-5eq). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ [ppm] 158.6, 154.8, 153.2, 140.7, 130.1, 126.1, 118.5, 117.8, 117.4, 110.3, 67.9, 67.7, 51.4, 45.7, 29.4; HRMS-ESI (m/z): for [C15H18N4O3 + H]+ calcd, 303.145; found, 303.145.

    Chiral Separation of Cis/Trans Mixtures

    Chiral separation of compounds R,R-36 and S,S-37 or R,S-38 and S,R-39, respectively, was performed on a preparative chiral HPLC column using an Agilent Technologies 1260 Infinity II LC System with Agilent InfinityLab single quadrupole LC/MSD system. Before chiral preparative separation, analytical runs were performed to evaluate a separation method using a Phenomenex Lux 5 μm i-Amylose 1 LC Column (250 × 4.6 mm). As appropriate separation method, a mixture of acetonitrile/methanol/glacial acetic acid/triethylamine (isocratic; 98:2:0.1:0.2; v/v/v/v) was chosen with a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min for 35 min. For preparative separation, a semi preparative chiral column from Phenomenex (Lux 5 μm i-Amylose 1 LC Column (250 × 10 mm)) was used. Acetonitrile/methanol/glacial acetic acid/triethylamine (isocratic; 98:2:0.1:0.2; v/v/v/v) was used as mobile phase with a flow rate of 2 mL/min over 35 min to elute the pure stereoisomers. The enantiomeric purity (95+%) was determined on the analytical column as described above (see the Supporting Information data).

    Protein Purification

    Bromodomains were produced following published protocols.(4) The buffers for the final gel filtration purification step on Superdex 75 varied for the different bromodomain variants purified. SMARCA2/4: 300 mM NaCl, 10 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 0.2 mM TCEP, 5% (v/v) glycerol. PB1(2/3/4): 150 mM NaCl, 20 mM HEPES (pH 7.4), 0.5 mM TCEP, 5% (v/v) glycerol. PB1(5): 500 mM NaCl, 10 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 0.2 mM TCEP, 5% (v/v) glycerol. Proteins samples were flash frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 °C.

    Differential Scanning Fluorimetry

    Ligand binding to proteins was detected using DSF on an MX3005P qPCR system from Agilent Technologies or a QuantStudio 5 Real-Time PCR System (384-well plates) from Thermo Fisher Scientific as described elsewhere.(75) Briefly, proteins were buffered in 10 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 150 mM NaCl and diluted to a final concentration of 2.5 μM (protein kinase domains) or 5.0 μM (bromodomains), and the fluorescent dye SYPRO Orange was added at a dilution of 1:1000. Compounds were dissolved in DMSO (50 mM) and added at a final concentration of 10 μM (protein kinases) or 20 μM (bromodomains) to 10 or 20 μL of protein-dye mix in a 96 or 384-well plate. Real-time melting curves were then recorded by heating the samples from 25 to 96 °C in 71 cycles (heating rate of 270 K/h, excitation/emission filters = 492/610 nm), and the melting point, Tm, was calculated using the Boltzmann equation.

    Isothermal Titration Calorimetry

    Binding constant (Kd), stoichiometry (n) and thermodynamic binding parameters (ΔH, ΔS and ΔG) of ligand–protein interactions were determined on a Nano-ITC from TA Instruments as described elsewhere.(76) Before measurement, the proteins were rebuffered to 20 mM HEPES (pH 7.5), 150 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM TCEP, and 5% glycerol by gel filtration. Compounds were diluted to a final concentration of 20–30 μM in buffer and placed into the sample cell. Proteins (125–200 μM) were added using an initial injection of 2 μL, followed by 27 injections of 8 μL at 15 or 25 °C. Collected data were corrected by subtraction of pure DMSO injection heats. Data were analyzed by assuming a sigmoidal dose–response relationship (four parameters). Errors of fits were calculated using standard deviation and a confidence interval of 95%.

    Crystallization and Structure Determination

    Crystals of bromodomain-inhibitor complexes were grown via the sitting drop vapor diffusion technique using a Mosquito crystallization robot (TTP Labtech) and SWISSCI 3-lens crystallization plates. Inhibitors were added at a threefold molar excess to the protein solution in gel filtration buffer (see above) prior to setting up the plates. Crystals were obtained under the following conditions. SMARCA4 with 23: 20% medium-molecular-weight PEG smear, 0.1 M Tris pH 8.5 (20 °C); PB1(5) with 23: 22% (w/v) PEG 3350, 0.2 M sodium malonate, 10% (v/v) ethylene glycol, 0.1 M bis-tris propane pH 7.1 (20 °C); PB1(5) with 22: 30% PEG 5000 MME, 0.2 M (NH4)2SO4, 0.1 M MES pH 5.8 (4 °C); PB1(2) with R-26: 0.2 M sodium chloride, 25% (w/v) PEG3350, 0.1 M bis-tris pH 5.5 (4 °C); PB1(2) with 32: 0.005 M zinc acetate, 20% (w/v) PEG 3350 (4 °C). Crystals were cryoprotected with mother liquor supplemented with 20% ethylene glycol and flash frozen in liquid nitrogen. X-ray data sets were collected at 100 K at BESSY beamline 14.2, Berlin, Germany, and beamline X06SA of the Swiss Light Source, Villigen, Switzerland. The diffraction data were integrated with either MOSFLM(77) or XDS,(78) and scaled with AIMLESS,(79) which is part of the CCP4 program suite.(80) The structures were solved by molecular replacement with PHASER,(81) using either PDB entry 5DKD (SMARCA4), 5FH7 (PB1(5)) or 3LJW (PB1(2)) as a starting model. Refinement of the structures was then performed by using iterative cycles of manual model building in COOT(82) and refinement in PHENIX.(83) Dictionary files for the ligands were generated using the Grade Web Server (http://grade.globalphasing.org). A summary of the data collection and refinement statistics is given in the Supporting Information Table S5. Structural figures were prepared using PyMOL (www.pymol.org).

    Cell Viability XTT Assay

    Cell viability was measured according to a published protocol.(84) Breast (MCF-7, MDA-MB-231) or colon (HCT116, SW480) cancer cells were seeded in 96-well plates (2 × 104 cells/well) in 200 μL of Dulbecco’s modified Eagle medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin streptomycin solution (10,000 units penicillin and 10 mg of streptomycin/mL; PS) or McCoy’s 5A medium (supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% PS) and incubated overnight at 37 °C in 5% CO2. Cells were treated with vehicle (DMSO) or increasing doses (1.5, 3.1, 6.3, 12.5, 25, 50, and 100 μM) of compounds R-28 and 22 for 72 h. Compounds were dispended using an Echo 550 liquid handler from Labcyte Inc. Before analysis, a mixture of 10 mL of media supplemented with 1 mg/mL XTT and 50 μL of 100 mM PMS in PBS (phosphate-buffered saline) was prepared. After compound treatment, the media was removed and 100 μL of the freshly prepared media mixture was added to each well. Cell viability/metabolic activity was measured on a PHERAstar FSX from BMG Labtech (absorbance: 450 nm, 660 nm) after 1 h. Blank signal was subtracted from results (media without cells).

    Adipocyte Differentiation

    All adipogenesis-related experiments were performed as previously described.(85) In general, 3T3-L1 cells were differentiated into adipocytes over 14 days according to the published protocol.(86) For this, cells were seeded in 6-well plates [2.5 × 105 cells/well, DMEM supplemented with 10% newborn calf serum, 1% PS and 1% sodium pyruvate], and differentiation was induced after 48 h by the addition of a differentiation cocktail containing 1 μg/mL insulin, 0.25 μM dexamethasone and 0.5 mM IBMX in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (FCS), 1% sodium pyruvate, and 1% PS. In addition, the PPARγ agonist rosiglitazone (2 μM) was added to stimulate and enhance differentiation. After 2 days, the medium was replaced by DMEM supplemented with 10% FCS, 1% sodium pyruvate, 1% PS and 1 μg/mL insulin, and the culture was grown for 2 more days. Then, cells were kept for lipid droplet accumulation in DMEM supplemented with 10% FCS, 1% sodium pyruvate and 1% PS until day 14. Compounds 22, R-28, 32, and the controls PFI-3 and 35 were added at 1 and 5 μM during seeding and kept at this concentration throughout the complete differentiation process (day 1–14). Compounds were refreshed after 48 and 96 h.

    Oil Red Staining

    Differentiated 3T3-L1 cells were washed with PBS and subsequently fixed for 60 min with formaldehyde (4% in PBS). Afterward, cells were thoroughly rinsed with 60% isopropanol and incubated with oil red O solution [0.3% in 60% (v/v) isopropanol] for 120 min. This was followed by the removal of the staining solution and thorough rinsing of the cell layer with ultrapure water. Finally, the plates were dried, and photos of the stained cell layers were taken.

    Analysis of Adipogenesis-Related Genes by qPCR

    3T3-L1 cells were differentiated into adipocytes for 7 days as described above. Samples were taken at indicated times and concentrations as provided in Figure 4b. After harvesting the samples and washing the cell pellets with PBS, the 3T3-L1 cells were lyzed using TRIzol reagent (Ambion Life Technologies). Subsequently, mRNA isolation was performed according to the manufacturers protocol. Remaining DNA impurities were digested using the DNAse I kit from Thermo Scientific, and mRNA integrity was confirmed on an agarose gel. In order to obtain cDNA, reverse transcription was performed using the High Capacity RNA-to-cDNA kit from Applied Biosystems according to the manufacturer’s protocol. qPCR was performed with Power SYBR Green Master Mix (Applied Biosystems) with a StepOnePlus Real-Time PCR system from Applied Biosystems using specific primers for murine as indicated in the Supporting Information Table S4. Relative mRNA expression was determined by the 2–ΔΔCT method compared to murine non-POU domain-containing octamer-binding protein (NONO). For incubation times and compound concentrations, see Figure 4b. All samples were measured in triplicates, and experiments were repeated independently at least three times.

    Accession Codes

    Coordinates and structure factors of the bromodomain-ligand complexes are available in the Protein Data Bank (PDB) under accession codes 6ZS2 (SMARCA4-23 complex), 6ZS3 (PB1(5)-23 complex), 6ZS4 (PB1(5)-22 complex), 6ZN6 (PB1(2)-R-26 complex), and 6ZNV (PB1(2)-32 complex).

    • Author Contributions

      M.W. synthesized all compounds and evaluated them in cellular experiments. M.W. and F.P. performed biophysical studies. F.P., X.N., A.K., S.M., D.H., and A.C.J. performed crystallographic studies. M.W., S.S., T.G., and A.S.K. performed and analyzed adipocyte stem cell differentiation experiments. M.W., A.C.J., and S.K. designed the study and wrote the manuscript.

    Abbreviations
    BAF

    BRG1- or BRM-associated factors

    BET

    bromodomain and extra-terminal motif

    BRD

    bromodomain

    BRG1

    brahma-related gene-1

    BRM

    brahma

    C/EBPα/β/δ

    CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein α/β/δ

    DSF

    differential scanning fluorimetry

    FABP4

    fatty acid-binding protein 4

    GLUT4

    glucose transporter type 4

    IBMX

    isobutylmethylxanthine

    ITC

    isothermal titration calorimetry

    KLF5

    Krüppel-like factor 5

    Krox20

    early growth response protein 2

    PBAF

    polybromo-associated BAF

    PBRM1/PB1

    polybromo 1

    PMS

    N-methyl dibenzopyrazine methyl sulfate

    PPARγ

    peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ

    PROTACs

    proteolysis targeting chimeras

    p300

    histone acetyltransferase p300

    qPCR

    quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction

    SMARCA2/4 or SMARCB1

    SWI/SNF-related matrix-associated actin-dependent regulator of chromatin, subfamily A2/4 or subfamily B1

    SWI/SNF

    switch/sucrose nonfermentable

    XTT

    2,3-bis-[(2-methoxy-4-nitro-5-sulfophenyl)-2H-tetrazolium-5-carboxanilide salt]

    References

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    This article references 87 other publications.

    1. 1
      Dawson, M. A.; Kouzarides, T. Cancer epigenetics: from mechanism to therapy. Cell 2012, 150, 12– 27,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2012.06.013
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Cancer Epigenetics: From Mechanism to Therapy
      Dawson, Mark A.; Kouzarides, Tony
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2012), 150 (1), 12-27CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. The epigenetic regulation of DNA-templated processes has been intensely studied over the last 15 years. DNA methylation, histone modification, nucleosome remodeling, and RNA-mediated targeting regulate many biol. processes that are fundamental to the genesis of cancer. Here, we present the basic principles behind these epigenetic pathways and highlight the evidence suggesting that their misregulation can culminate in cancer. This information, along with the promising clin. and preclin. results seen with epigenetic drugs against chromatin regulators, signifies that it is time to embrace the central role of epigenetics in cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XpvFGjsLg%253D&md5=bc0176364205a2e66e1971fe789d36ae
    2. 2
      Klemm, S. L.; Shipony, Z.; Greenleaf, W. J. Chromatin accessibility and the regulatory epigenome. Nat. Rev. Genet. 2019, 20, 207– 220,  DOI: 10.1038/s41576-018-0089-8
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Chromatin accessibility and the regulatory epigenome
      Klemm, Sandy L.; Shipony, Zohar; Greenleaf, William J.
      Nature Reviews Genetics (2019), 20 (4), 207-220CODEN: NRGAAM; ISSN:1471-0056. (Nature Research)
      A review. Phys. access to DNA is a highly dynamic property of chromatin that plays an essential role in establishing and maintaining cellular identity. The organization of accessible chromatin across the genome reflects a network of permissible phys. interactions through which enhancers, promoters, insulators and chromatin-binding factors cooperatively regulate gene expression. This landscape of accessibility changes dynamically in response to both external stimuli and developmental cues, and emerging evidence suggests that homeostatic maintenance of accessibility is itself dynamically regulated through a competitive interplay between chromatin-binding factors and nucleosomes. In this Review, we examine how the accessible genome is measured and explore the role of transcription factors in initiating accessibility remodeling; our goal is to illustrate how chromatin accessibility defines regulatory elements within the genome and how these epigenetic features are dynamically established to control gene expression.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmtFGqsbk%253D&md5=60707e7c4467e9f7b0edbba256e66832
    3. 3
      Owen, D. J.; Ornaghi, P.; Yang, J. C.; Lowe, N.; Evans, P. R.; Ballario, P.; Neuhaus, D.; Filetici, P.; Travers, A. A. The structural basis for the recognition of acetylated histone H4 by the bromodomain of histone acetyltransferase gcn5p. EMBO J. 2000, 19, 6141– 6149,  DOI: 10.1093/emboj/19.22.6141
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      The structural basis for the recognition of acetylated histone H4 by the bromodomain of histone acetyltransferase Gcn5p
      Owen, David J.; Ornaghi, Prisca; Yang, Ji-Chun; Lowe, Nicholas; Evans, Philip R.; Ballario, Paola; Neuhaus, David; Filetici, Patrizia; Travers, Andrew A.
      EMBO Journal (2000), 19 (22), 6141-6149CODEN: EMJODG; ISSN:0261-4189. (Oxford University Press)
      The bromodomain is an ∼110 amino acid module found in histone acetyltransferases and the ATPase component of certain nucleosome remodeling complexes. We report the crystal structure at 1.9 Å resoln. of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Gcn5p bromodomain complexed with a peptide corresponding to residues 15-29 of histone H4 acetylated at the ζ-N of lysine 16. We show that this bromodomain preferentially binds to peptides contg. an N-acetyl lysine residue. Only residues 16-19 of the acetylated peptide interact with the bromodomain. The primary interaction is the N-acetyl lysine binding in a cleft with the specificity provided by the interaction of the amide nitrogen of a conserved asparagine with the oxygen of the acetyl carbonyl group. A network of water-mediated H-bonds with protein main chain carbonyl groups at the base of the cleft contributes to the binding. Addnl. side chain binding occurs on a shallow depression that is hydrophobic at one end and can accommodate charge interactions at the other. These findings suggest that the Gcn5p bromodomain may discriminate between different acetylated lysine residues depending on the context in which they are displayed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXovVaitro%253D&md5=1cc0a6434f61362e83830becc7bdc594
    4. 4
      Filippakopoulos, P.; Picaud, S.; Mangos, M.; Keates, T.; Lambert, J.-P.; Barsyte-Lovejoy, D.; Felletar, I.; Volkmer, R.; Müller, S.; Pawson, T.; Gingras, A.-C.; Arrowsmith, C. H.; Knapp, S. Histone recognition and large-scale structural analysis of the human bromodomain family. Cell 2012, 149, 214– 231,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2012.02.013
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Histone Recognition and Large-Scale Structural Analysis of the Human Bromodomain Family
      Filippakopoulos, Panagis; Picaud, Sarah; Mangos, Maria; Keates, Tracy; Lambert, Jean-Philippe; Barsyte-Lovejoy, Dalia; Felletar, Ildiko; Volkmer, Rudolf; Muller, Susanne; Pawson, Tony; Gingras, Anne-Claude; Arrowsmith, Cheryl H.; Knapp, Stefan
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2012), 149 (1), 214-231CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Bromodomains (BRDs) are protein interaction modules that specifically recognize ε-N-lysine acetylation motifs, a key event in the reading process of epigenetic marks. The 61 BRDs in the human genome cluster into eight families based on structure/sequence similarity. Here, we present 29 high-resoln. crystal structures, covering all BRD families. These proteins are: ASH1L, ATAD2, BAZ2B, BPTF, BRD1, BRD3(1), BRD3(2), BRD4(1), BRD4(2), BRD9, BRDT(1), CECR2, EP300, CREBBP, GCN5L2, KIAA1240, PB1(1), PB1(2), PB1(3), PB1(4), PB1(5), PB1(6), PCAF, PHIP(2), TAF1(2), WDR9(2), BRD4(1). Comprehensive crossfamily structural anal. identifies conserved and family-specific structural features that are necessary for specific acetylation-dependent substrate recognition. Screening of more than 30 representative BRDs against systematic histone-peptide arrays identifies new BRD substrates and reveals a strong influence of flanking posttranslational modifications, such as acetylation and phosphorylation, suggesting that BRDs recognize combinations of marks rather than singly acetylated sequences. We further uncovered a structural mechanism for the simultaneous binding and recognition of diverse diacetyl-contg. peptides by BRD4. These data provide a foundation for structure-based drug design of specific inhibitors for this emerging target family.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XltVamurs%253D&md5=05583a01a1cd4c3b59fc59c00e4c4777
    5. 5
      Muller, S.; Filippakopoulos, P.; Knapp, S. Bromodomains as therapeutic targets. Expert Rev. Mol. Med. 2011, 13, e29  DOI: 10.1017/s1462399411001992
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Bromodomains as therapeutic targets
      Muller, Susanne; Filippakopoulos, Panagis; Knapp, Stefan
      Expert Reviews in Molecular Medicine (2011), 13 (), e29/1-e29/21CODEN: ERMMFS; ISSN:1462-3994. (Cambridge University Press)
      A review. Acetylation of lysine residues is a post-translational modification with broad relevance to cellular signalling and disease biol. Enzymes that 'write' (histone acetyltransferases, HATs) and 'erase' (histone deacetylases, HDACs) acetylation sites are an area of extensive research in current drug development, but very few potent inhibitors that modulate the 'reading process' mediated by acetyl lysines have been described. The principal readers of ε-N-acetyl lysine (Kac) marks are bromodomains (BRDs), which are a diverse family of evolutionary conserved protein-interaction modules. The conserved BRD fold contains a deep, largely hydrophobic acetyl lysine binding site, which represents an attractive pocket for the development of small, pharmaceutically active mols. Proteins that contain BRDs have been implicated in the development of a large variety of diseases. Recently, two highly potent and selective inhibitors that target BRDs of the BET (bromodomains and extra-terminal) family provided compelling data supporting targeting of these BRDs in inflammation and in an aggressive type of squamous cell carcinoma. It is likely that BRDs will emerge alongside HATs and HDACs as interesting targets for drug development for the large no. of diseases that are caused by aberrant acetylation of lysine residues.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1OhurjI&md5=dc9383afcbe6aedc265041c21213aa0b
    6. 6
      Filippakopoulos, P.; Knapp, S. Targeting bromodomains: epigenetic readers of lysine acetylation. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2014, 13, 337– 356,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd4286
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Targeting bromodomains: epigenetic readers of lysine acetylation
      Filippakopoulos, Panagis; Knapp, Stefan
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2014), 13 (5), 337-356CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Lysine acetylation is a key mechanism that regulates chromatin structure; aberrant acetylation levels have been linked to the development of several diseases. Acetyl-lysine modifications create docking sites for bromodomains, which are small interaction modules found on diverse proteins, some of which have a key role in the acetylation-dependent assembly of transcriptional regulator complexes. These complexes can then initiate transcriptional programs that result in phenotypic changes. The recent discovery of potent and highly specific inhibitors for the BET (bromodomain and extra-terminal) family of bromodomains has stimulated intensive research activity in diverse therapeutic areas, particularly in oncol., where BET proteins regulate the expression of key oncogenes and anti-apoptotic proteins. In addn., targeting BET bromodomains could hold potential for the treatment of inflammation and viral infection. Here, we highlight recent progress in the development of bromodomain inhibitors, and their potential applications in drug discovery.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXmsFalsr4%253D&md5=77049c82ce6a19b4685e3b7950399a07
    7. 7
      Filippakopoulos, P.; Qi, J.; Picaud, S.; Shen, Y.; Smith, W. B.; Fedorov, O.; Morse, E. M.; Keates, T.; Hickman, T. T.; Felletar, I.; Philpott, M.; Munro, S.; McKeown, M. R.; Wang, Y.; Christie, A. L.; West, N.; Cameron, M. J.; Schwartz, B.; Heightman, T. D.; La Thangue, N.; French, C. A.; Wiest, O.; Kung, A. L.; Knapp, S.; Bradner, J. E. Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains. Nature 2010, 468, 1067– 1073,  DOI: 10.1038/nature09504
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Selective inhibition of BET bromodomains
      Filippakopoulos, Panagis; Qi, Jun; Picaud, Sarah; Shen, Yao; Smith, William B.; Fedorov, Oleg; Morse, Elizabeth M.; Keates, Tracey; Hickman, Tyler T.; Felletar, Ildiko; Philpott, Martin; Munro, Shongah; McKeown, Michael R.; Wang, Yuchuan; Christie, Amanda L.; West, Nathan; Cameron, Michael J.; Schwartz, Brian; Heightman, Tom D.; La Thangue, Nicholas; French, Christopher; Wiest, Olaf; Kung, Andrew L.; Knapp, Stefan; Bradner, James E.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2010), 468 (7327), 1067-1073CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Epigenetic proteins are intently pursued targets in ligand discovery. So far, successful efforts have been limited to chromatin modifying enzymes, or so-called epigenetic 'writers' and 'erasers'. Potent inhibitors of histone binding modules have not yet been described. Here the authors report a cell-permeable small mol. (I,JQ1) that binds competitively to acetyl-lysine recognition motifs, or bromodomains. High potency and specificity towards a subset of human bromodomains is explained by co-crystal structures with bromodomain and extra-terminal (BET) family member BRD4, revealing excellent shape complementarity with the acetyl-lysine binding cavity. Recurrent translocation of BRD4 is obsd. in a genetically-defined, incurable subtype of human squamous carcinoma. Competitive binding by JQ1 displaces the BRD4 fusion oncoprotein from chromatin, prompting squamous differentiation and specific antiproliferative effects in BRD4-dependent cell lines and patient-derived xenograft models. These data establish proof-of-concept for targeting protein-protein interactions of epigenetic 'readers', and provide a versatile chem. scaffold for the development of chem. probes more broadly throughout the bromodomain family.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXotlGmtA%253D%253D&md5=bd9cadac86124d2c6c3cd5b2a92d68c2
